study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure activity levels in older and younger hospital inpatients to assess mobility and inform quality-improvement interventions.
results_summary: The study found that inpatients spent most of their time lying in bed (57%) and only 9% standing or walking, with no significant differences between older and younger subgroups but variations among wards.
population_specificity: Hospital inpatients (older ≥65 years and younger <65 years) in medical, surgical, and oncology wards.
study_duration: Observations were conducted over 4, 4-hour daytime periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate hypoglycaemia and its consequences in T2DM patients in non-Western countries and suggest suitable guidelines for these transitioning communities.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Walking's effects, as it focuses on hypoglycaemia and diabetes complications in non-Western countries.
population_specificity: T2DM patients in middle-income, non-Western countries transitioning from poverty to affluence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between muscle architecture, function, and behavior during activities like walking, as well as the remodeling of muscle in response to loading, unloading, and aging.
results_summary: The study found that muscle architecture and fiber contractile properties significantly influence mechanical properties, with recent technologies enabling in vivo observation of fascicle and sarcomere behavior during walking. It also identified contraction-mode-dependent muscle hypertrophy patterns and clinical biomarkers for disuse atrophy and sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human muscle physiology)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rivastigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, could reduce gait variability and improve gait stability in Parkinson's disease patients with a history of falls.
results_summary: The study found that rivastigmine significantly improved step time variability during normal walking and a simple dual task compared to placebo, but not during a complex dual task. Gastrointestinal side-effects like nausea and vomiting were more common in the rivastigmine group.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease who had fallen at least once in the previous year, could walk 18 m unaided, had no dementia, and no prior exposure to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
effective_dosage: Rivastigmine was uptitrated from 3 mg/day to a target dose of 12 mg/day (taken twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively quantify activity and sleep quality in hemodialysis patients and assess the effect of providing feedback on activity levels.
results_summary: The study found that hemodialysis patients walked an average of 8,454 steps/day, with significantly fewer steps on Sundays. Providing feedback did not increase activity, and poor sleep quality was noted, particularly for those with early morning dialysis shifts.
population_specificity: Chronic hemodialysis patients in an urban population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the responsiveness of different exercise tests, including walking tests, in assessing the effects of pulmonary rehabilitation in COPD patients.
results_summary: All exercise tests, including walking tests (6MWT, ISWT, ESWT), were responsive to pulmonary rehabilitation, with similar numbers of participants exceeding clinically important differences. Laboratory cycling tests showed slightly higher effect sizes than walking tests, but the clinical significance of this difference requires further study.
population_specificity: 15 male patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and challenges of robotic rehabilitation devices in improving walking ability for patients with neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study found that robotic rehabilitation systems, including stationary and overground walking devices, are useful for improving gait in patients with severe acquired brain injury, spinal cord injury, and other neurological diseases. Novel tools like virtual reality were also highlighted as promising for rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological disorders (e.g., acquired brain injury, spinal cord injury, Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the administration method (self-administration vs. face-to-face interview) or interviewer type (vascular surgeon vs. general practitioner) affected the results of the WIQ and EQ-5D questionnaires in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found a strong correlation (r > 0.800) and high concordance (P > 0.05) between self-administered and face-to-face questionnaire methods, as well as between interviewer types (vascular surgeon and general practitioner), indicating no significant differences in outcomes.
population_specificity: 1,641 patients with intermittent claudication within the Spanish National Health Service.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of PR-fampridine on walking function and identify associated gait modifications in subjects with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: PR-fampridine improved walking speed, endurance, and everyday physical activity in a subset of MS subjects, with gait pattern changes correlating with these improvements. Responders showed significant increases in walking speed (T25FW) and distance (6MWT).
population_specificity: Subjects with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between dangerous student car drop-off behaviors and historical child pedestrian-motor vehicle collisions (PMVCs) near elementary schools.
results_summary: Dangerous drop-off behaviors were associated with a 45% increase in collision rates, with higher speed roads and social disadvantage also linked to higher collision rates. The study suggests targeted interventions could reduce child PMVCs and promote safe walking to school.
population_specificity: Elementary school children in Toronto, Canada.
study_duration: Data collected over 12 years (2000-2011), with driving behavior observed on a single day in 2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to construct preoperative risk scores for preventable complications, including those related to mobility (e.g., falls, mobilisation issues) in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study identified that patients with certain preoperative characteristics (e.g., age ≥ 80, use of walking aids) had higher risks of preventable medical complications, such as falls and mobilisation issues. However, no clinically relevant prediction was possible for surgical complications.
population_specificity: 8,373 consecutive patients undergoing elective primary unilateral total hip or knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of walking with a pedometer on sleep quality in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that walking with a pedometer significantly improved multiple aspects of sleep quality, including sleep latency, duration, efficiency, and daytime dysfunction, compared to the control group. The total sleep quality score was significantly higher in the intervention group after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal Iranian women (n=112).
effective_dosage: Increasing walking distance by 500 steps per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isolated ACTH deficiency could be a significant differential diagnosis for idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH) in patients presenting with gait disturbance.
results_summary: The study found that corticosteroid therapy improved gait disturbance in a patient with isolated ACTH deficiency, suggesting this condition should be considered in the differential diagnosis of iNPH. The patient's symptoms improved promptly after treatment.
population_specificity: A 69-year-old female with progressive gait disturbance and suspected iNPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on correlates and determinants of physical activity, particularly walking, in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: The study found consistent associations between walking limitations, disability level, self-efficacy, self-regulation, employment status, and educational level with physical activity in pwMS. One intervention suggested a causal link between self-regulation and physical activity, but most evidence was cross-sectional.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare birth history and postnatal complications between children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW) and those with a medical reason for toe walking.
results_summary: Children with ITW had higher rates of prematurity, admission to special care nurseries, and lower birth weights compared to normative data. Children with a medical reason for toe walking also showed higher prematurity rates and more instrumented births than the ITW cohort.
population_specificity: Children presenting to a toe-walking clinic (ages ~5.8 years, 63-68% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of sildenafil when coadministered with bosentan (S+B) versus ambrisentan (S+A) in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension, focusing on walking performance.
results_summary: The study found that sildenafil's plasma concentration was higher and oral clearance lower with S+A compared to S+B. Walking distance improved more with S+A (340 m) than with S+B (280 m), with no safety concerns for either combination.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
interactions: Sildenafil interacted differently with bosentan and ambrisentan, affecting its pharmacokinetics and walking outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if progressive resistance training is effective for rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease compared to other treatments or no treatment.
results_summary: The study found no evidence supporting the superiority of progressive resistance training over other physical training methods for Parkinson's disease rehabilitation, with pooled effect sizes below minimal clinical significance for outcomes like walking speed and endurance tests.
population_specificity: Adults with primary/idiopathic Parkinson's disease of any severity, excluding other concurrent neurological conditions.
study_duration: None or 1 month follow-up after intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an exercise program focusing on hip external rotator muscles could improve physical recovery, including walking ability, in the early post-operative period of total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The study found that the exercise program significantly improved hip abductor strength and walking ability (measured by the TUG test) in the acute post-THA stage. The effect sizes were moderate (0.60 for hip abductor strength and -0.53 for TUG test).
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty (THA) (n=28, split into exercise and control groups).
effective_dosage: Hip external rotator exercise program performed 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of a respiratory filter intervention during controlled pollution exposure on heart failure patients and control volunteers, focusing on endothelial function, arterial stiffness, serum biomarkers, 6-min walking distance, and heart rate variability.
results_summary: Diesel exhaust (DE) worsened endothelial function and increased BNP in heart failure patients, while filtration improved these markers. DE decreased 6-min walking distance and arterial stiffness in both groups, but filtration did not reverse these effects.
population_specificity: 26 patients with heart failure and 15 control volunteers.
study_duration: Three separate exposure sessions (clean air, unfiltered DE, filtered DE)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the signal quality of dry electrodes versus wet electrodes during walking and other motion tasks for EEG measurements.
results_summary: The study found that dry electrodes (foam-based and spring-loaded) showed high correlation in signal quality with wet electrodes during walking and cycling, with similar susceptibility to artifacts. Dry electrodes were deemed more practical for mobile applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general population undergoing EEG measurements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between neighborhood environments, physical activity (including walking), quality of life, and depressive symptoms in older adults.
results_summary: The study assessed neighborhood walkability and access to destinations, finding associations with physical activity, quality of life, and depressive symptoms, though specific results on walking's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Hong Kong older adults aged 65+ years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if foot motion patterns, including walking, could predict postural instability in Parkinson's disease patients using wearable sensors.
results_summary: The study found that foot motion data, including walking, could estimate postural instability with a mean classification probability of 0.75. Walking with stop-and-go was particularly effective for tremor-dominant patients.
population_specificity: 139 idiopathic Parkinson's disease patients (bradykinetic, tremor-dominant, or equivalent phenotypes).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the impact of walking on symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), particularly how it exacerbates pain and disability.
results_summary: The study found that walking exacerbates symptoms of LSS, such as pain in the buttocks or lower extremities, and is associated with reduced space for neural and vascular elements in the lumbar spine. Non-surgical management options, including lifestyle modification, were noted, but evidence for their efficacy was insufficient.
population_specificity: Adults with lumbar spinal stenosis, particularly those over 65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the advantages and complications of intramedullary nailing for treating pertrochanteric femoral fractures, with a focus on postoperative walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that intramedullary nailing improves postoperative walking ability, among other benefits, but also introduces a new set of complications, many related to technical errors.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with pertrochanteric fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity levels (sitting, standing, walking) among stroke survivors during hospital stays versus community living with early supported discharge.
results_summary: After early supported discharge, participants took more than twice the number of steps and spent double the time standing compared to their hospital stay, indicating significantly increased physical activity. The study concluded that community living with early supported discharge promotes higher activity levels in stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Forty-one stroke survivors (mean age 69 years) in the UK with a median Modified Rivermead Mobility Index of 33.5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively assess the effects of elevated vacuum suspension (EVS) on residual-limb circulation, skin health, and perfusion in individuals with lower-limb amputation.
results_summary: EVS improved residual-limb oxygenation during treadmill walking and attenuated prosthesis-induced reactive hyperemia after 16 weeks of use. It also preserved skin barrier function compared to the control socket.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower-limb amputation (N = 10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mirror therapy combined with electrical stimulation (ES) versus conventional therapy in improving lower extremity function in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of mirror therapy and ES significantly improved ankle dorsi-flexion range of motion, lower extremity sensory-motor function, and walking duration compared to conventional therapy, with results maintained at a 4-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Sub-acute stroke survivors (n=18).
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention phase, with a 1-week rest between phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of Wii.n.Walk, a Wii Fit-based training program, for improving walking capacity in older adults with lower limb amputation.
results_summary: The study found that Wii.n.Walk had medium effect sizes for improving walking capacity (0.5-1.2), high adherence (83.4%), and positive perceived benefit (38.9/45). A future larger RCT with 72 participants was deemed necessary to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥50 years) with unilateral lower limb amputation.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week (40 minutes each) for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of autologous bone marrow stem cell therapy in restoring function, including walking, in patients with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that walking, at least with support, was restored in eight out of ten patients, alongside improvements in ASIA grades, bladder control, sexual functions, and reduced spasticity.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury, particularly those with injury duration less than 6 months.
effective_dosage: 5 ml of processed autologous bone marrow stem cells injected via lumbar puncture every 4 weeks for 3 times (12 weeks total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of exercise training, particularly walking, on vascular function, inflammation, hemostasis, oxidative stress, and quality of life in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: Exercise training, especially walking, significantly improved walking distance, cardiovascular parameters, and quality of life in peripheral arterial disease patients. It also helped control hypertension, hyperglycemia, obesity, and dyslipidemia, reducing overall cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease, particularly those with intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise training for 30-45 minutes, at least three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimally important difference (MID) for absolute claudication distance (ACD) and functional claudication distance (FCD) in patients with intermittent claudication (IC) to assess clinically relevant changes in walking distance after supervised exercise therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the MID for ACD was 305 m for improvement and 147 m for deterioration, while the MID for FCD was 250 m for improvement and 120 m for deterioration, providing benchmarks for clinically meaningful changes in walking distance.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC) receiving supervised exercise therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative progressive resistance training (PRT) combined with postoperative PRT improves functional performance, muscle strength, and patient-reported outcomes in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to postoperative PRT alone.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative PRT significantly improved postoperative functional performance (30sCST, TUG) and muscle strength (knee extensor and flexor) compared to the control group, though no differences were observed in patient-reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (progressive resistance training regimen details not provided).
study_duration: 4 weeks preoperative PRT (intervention group) + 4 weeks postoperative PRT (both groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity levels, including walking, in individuals with anorexia nervosa at different treatment stages and against healthy controls.
results_summary: Patients with anorexia nervosa became more physically active after weight restoration and post-treatment, particularly in standing and walking, compared to healthy controls. Greater time spent on feet during weight restoration was associated with faster BMI decline post-treatment.
population_specificity: Female inpatients with anorexia nervosa and healthy female controls.
study_duration: Measurements taken at low-weight, weight-restored, and one month post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the causes, epidemiology, diagnosis, and treatment options for toe walking, focusing on recent literature.
results_summary: The study found that toe walking prevalence is 2% in normally developing children and 41% in those with neuropsychiatric or developmental conditions. Casting and surgery showed good evidence for treatment, with surgery providing long-term results, while Botox combined with casting did not outperform casting alone.
population_specificity: Normally developing children and children with neuropsychiatric diagnoses or developmental delays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of road traffic injuries among children during school commutes in Hyderabad, India, focusing on different travel modes, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that 17% of children reported road injuries during school journeys, with boys more affected than girls. Walking was safer than cycling but less safe than traveling by school bus.
population_specificity: Children (n=5842) traveling to school in Hyderabad, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathoanatomy, natural history, and treatment of crouch gait, a common gait disorder in patients with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that crouch gait is highly ineffective and may compromise walking ability over time, often requiring surgical intervention. Surgical correction of joint contractures and lever arm dysfunction can be effectively achieved through single-event multilevel surgery.
population_specificity: Ambulatory diplegic and quadriplegic patients with cerebral palsy, particularly those reaching the pubertal spurt.

study_goal: To evaluate the methodologic quality of evidence for spinal manipulative therapy (SMT) with and without other therapies in managing COPD, including its effects on walking performance.
results_summary: Five of six studies reported improvements in lung function and exercise performance (including the six-minute walking test) following SMT intervention, particularly when combined with exercise. However, the RCTs had small sample sizes, limiting generalizability.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 with diagnosed COPD (ages 55–85).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week neuromuscular and strength training program could reduce knee joint loading during walking and stair climbing in obese children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study evaluated the biomechanical and clinical effects of the training program, focusing on knee joint loading, kinematics, and kinetics, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese children and adolescents aged 10-18 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (training program details not provided in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the recovery of walking function and daily activities in patients with ICU-acquired muscle weakness.
results_summary: Most patients achieved recovery of walking function after a median of 28.5 days post-rehabilitation and 81.5 days post-illness onset. Secondary outcomes, except pain, improved significantly within the first 8 weeks.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with ICU-acquired muscle weakness in post-acute ICU and rehabilitation units in Germany.
study_duration: Median recovery time was 28.5 days post-rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding an individual activity counseling program to pulmonary rehabilitation could enhance daily physical activity levels, specifically walking time and moderate-intensity activity, in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The study found no significant additional effect of activity counseling on daily walking time or moderate-intensity activity levels in COPD patients. Both the intervention and control groups showed no significant changes in physical activity levels over time.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to very severe COPD (66 ± 7 years, 81% male, FEV1 45 ± 16% predicted).
effective_dosage: Eight individual activity counseling sessions during pulmonary rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of very early enzyme-replacement therapy (ERT) on clinical outcomes, including developmental milestones like walking, in infants with Pompe disease.
results_summary: The study found that early ERT resulted in normal developmental outcomes, with the mean age for independent walking (11.6 ± 1.3 months) matching that of healthy children. No hearing or vision abnormalities were reported.
population_specificity: Newborns diagnosed with infantile-onset Pompe disease (IOPD) in a nationwide screening program.
study_duration: Follow-up period included at least 2 years of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether augmenting the cholinergic system with donepezil could improve balance and gait in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study is exploratory and does not yet report results, but it hypothesizes that changes in cholinergic activity will predict donepezil's effectiveness on gait and balance.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease, Hoehn and Yahr stages 2 to 4.
effective_dosage: Donepezil at 5 mg/day initially, increased to 10 mg/day after 3 weeks if tolerated.
study_duration: Each treatment period was 6 weeks with a 6-week washout, totaling 18 weeks per subject.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cycle ergometer training versus treadmill training on gait improvement and clinical signs in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Both cycle ergometer and treadmill training significantly improved walking parameters (6MWT, speed, step length, cadence), balance (Mini-BESTest), and clinical signs (UPDRS) in PD patients to a similar degree, making gait patterns closer to those of healthy subjects.
population_specificity: 29 inpatients with Parkinson's disease (Hoehn-Yahr staging not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between serum biomarkers of cartilage metabolism and peak vertical ground-reaction force (vGRF) during walking in individuals with ACL reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: Lower C2C:CPII ratios (indicating lower collagen breakdown relative to synthesis) were associated with higher peak vGRF in the ACLR limb during walking, suggesting a potential metabolic compensation to increased loading. No significant associations were found between vGRF loading rate and other cartilage biomarkers.
population_specificity: 19 individuals with a history of primary unilateral ACLR who had returned to unrestricted physical activity.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking at self-selected comfortable speed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dancing intervention could improve gait variability and local dynamic stability in older adults compared to a health-related exercise group.
results_summary: The study found no significant interaction effect on trunk movement variability but observed improved local dynamic stability in the dancing group, suggesting dancing may enhance walking stability in older adults.
population_specificity: 32 older healthy participants (mean age ~67-68 years, BMI ~26-27, mixed gender).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding an exercise and counseling intervention to standard smoking cessation treatment would improve abstinence, reduce depressive symptoms, and increase physical activity in smokers with depressive disorders.
results_summary: The intervention group showed no significant difference in smoking abstinence or depressive symptoms compared to the control group but outperformed in the 6-minute walking test and perceived physical control. The study suggests potential benefits of exercise and counseling for physical outcomes, though not for smoking cessation or mood.
population_specificity: Smokers with current depressive disorders (70 participants, 60% female, mixed marital and educational status).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions over 8 weeks (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To determine if the six-minute walk test (6MWT) and incremental shuttle walking test (ISWT) produce cardiovascular and metabolic responses comparable to cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPX) and if they are interchangeable in obese and eutrophic individuals.
results_summary: The study found agreement between CPX and both 6MWT and ISWT in obese women, with strong correlations between key variables (VO2, dyspnoea, and leg fatigue). The tests showed similar cardiovascular and metabolic responses in obese women but not in controls, suggesting interchangeability in clinical settings for this population.
population_specificity: 51 obese women (ObG) and 21 controls (CG), aged 20-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of walking status on the progression of scoliosis in individuals with Rett syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that scoliosis progression was reduced in individuals who could walk independently or with assistance, and walking ability at age 10 could predict severe scoliosis by age 16.
population_specificity: Individuals with Rett syndrome in Australia.
study_duration: Longitudinal observational study (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of exercise therapy and patient education on range of motion, muscle strength, physical fitness, walking capacity, and pain during walking in people with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant group differences in range of motion, muscle strength, physical fitness, or walking capacity, but the exercise group reported less pain during walking at 10 and 29 months compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 109 people with clinically and radiographically evident hip osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 2 or 3 weekly sessions of strengthening, functional, and stretching exercises over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of tuberculosis meningitis presenting with walking instability and associated neurological complications.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a woman with walking instability, intracerebral hemorrhage, and leptomeningeal enhancement due to tuberculosis meningitis, highlighting diagnostic challenges. No direct effects or outcomes related to walking were assessed.
population_specificity: A single female patient with no significant medical history presenting with walking instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion of older adults who recognize their falls risk and prioritize fall-preventive care, as well as factors associated with this prioritization.
results_summary: Only 16% of at-risk participants recognized their falls risk, and 10% prioritized it. Prioritization was associated with recurrent falls, severe fear-of-falling, and walking aid use. Fall incidence was higher in the priority group initially but leveled out after 12 months.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 70+ at risk of functional decline in the Netherlands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Masai Barefoot Technology (MBT) footwear on lower limb biomechanics during walking gait.
results_summary: MBT footwear altered lower limb biomechanics in asymptomatic individuals, including shorter stride length, reduced peak hip flexion, and increased peak knee extension. In symptomatic individuals, no significant effects were observed except for changes in cadence and step length in those with tibiotalar arthrodesis.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic individuals and symptomatic individuals (with knee osteoarthritis, post-total knee replacement, or post-tibiotalar arthrodesis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of heated water-based walking (HEx) versus land-based walking (LEx) on ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) in heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: Both HEx and LEx reduced daytime diastolic blood pressure compared to the control, with HEx showing a more significant reduction. Hourly analysis revealed lower systolic and diastolic BP values after both exercises, but no significant differences were found between HEx and LEx.
population_specificity: Clinically stable heart transplant recipients (18 participants, 6 females, average age 45.7 years, average time since surgery 5.0 years).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking at an intensity of 11-13 on the 6-20 RPE scale.
study_duration: Single 30-minute sessions for each intervention (HEx, LEx, and CON), with 2-5 days between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if treadmill belt accelerations and decelerations could evoke reflexes in the gastrocnemius, soleus, and tibialis anterior muscles during walking in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill perturbations caused clear changes in muscle length and stretch velocity, leading to bursts in muscle activity in stretched muscles and depressions in shortened muscles, with effects increasing with perturbation intensity. Normal walking was largely retained, indicating that treadmill perturbations can functionally measure reflexes during gait.
population_specificity: 10 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of trimetazidine (TMZ) in addition to standard treatment on exercise tolerance, including walking performance, in patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD).
results_summary: TMZ significantly improved exercise tolerance, including 6-minute walking test (6-MWT) performance, in IHD patients, with greater benefits observed in those with heart failure. However, no significant improvement was found in diabetic participants.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD), including subgroups with or without heart failure and diabetes.
study_duration: Subgroup analysis included 3-month and 6-month intervention periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether karate or fitness training could improve gait parameters and reduce fall risk in older adults, particularly under dual-task conditions.
results_summary: All groups, including the control, showed improved gait parameters after 5 months, with sport interventions primarily benefiting temporal gait parameters during normal walking and cognitive dual tasks. Karate and fitness training improved walking performance even under dual-task conditions.
population_specificity: 68 people with a mean age of 69 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) versus conventional physiotherapy on walking ability, depression, fatigue, and quality of life in progressive MS patients with severe gait disability.
results_summary: RAGT improved walking endurance and balance significantly, with positive effects on depression in both groups. Only RAGT increased perceived physical functioning QoL, but no significant effects on fatigue were observed.
population_specificity: Progressive multiple sclerosis patients with severe gait disability (Expanded Disability Status Scale score 6-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and impact of theory-based walking interventions delivered by practice nurses in primary care settings for increasing physical activity among adults and older adults.
results_summary: The study identified key enablers and barriers to delivering the intervention, including preparation, support, protocol adherence, materials, and participant engagement. Nurses reported that participation enhanced their consultation quality, though time constraints remained a challenge.
population_specificity: Adults and older adults in primary care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the physical benefits of therapeutic horseback riding and hippotherapy, particularly focusing on improvements in gross motor functions like walking, and suggest future research directions.
results_summary: The study found that equine-assisted activities and therapies led to acute and residual improvements in walking, posture, balance, and gait in adults and children with disabilities, with the greatest benefits observed after multiweek interventions. Modest cardiovascular responses were noted during activities, but no significant training improvements in heart rate or blood pressure were observed.
population_specificity: Adults and children with varying disabilities.
effective_dosage: One or more sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of treatment with a percutaneous compression plate (PCCP) in stable and unstable intertrochanteric hip fractures, focusing on factors like pain, walking ability, and complications.
results_summary: Patients with unstable fractures experienced significantly worse postoperative pain and delayed independent walking ability at 6 weeks compared to those with stable fractures. No other significant differences were observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients older than 65 years undergoing surgery for intertrochanteric hip fractures (n = 657), divided into stable (n = 363) and unstable (n = 294) fracture groups.
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 weeks and 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare intermediate-term patient-reported outcomes, including walking/standing, between cruciate-retaining and posterior-stabilized total knee arthroplasty (TKA) prostheses.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in walking/standing scores or other patient-reported outcomes between the two TKA prosthesis types after an average 8-year follow-up. Both groups showed similar results in range of motion and radiographic alignment postoperatively.
population_specificity: 60 patients (48 assessed) with varus-type osteoarthritis who underwent TKA (30 cruciate-retaining, 30 posterior-stabilized).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a Health Promotion Program (HPP), including walking, on behavior and lifestyle dimensions in post-CABG patients.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group, which included walking as part of the intervention, showed significant improvements in stress management, diet, spiritual growth, and interpersonal relationships compared to the control group. Walking was part of a broader health promotion program, but its specific effects were not isolated in the results.
population_specificity: Patients who had undergone Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individually tailored interventions using 3D instrumented gait analysis (IGA) improve gait more effectively than standard care ("care as usual") in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study compares gait improvements between IGA-based interventions and standard care, with primary outcomes measured by the Gait Deviation Index and secondary outcomes including walking performance and patient-reported functional mobility, quality of life, and participation. Results are pending as the study is prospective and not yet completed.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-8 years with spastic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I or II).
study_duration: 52 weeks (primary endpoint), with a 26-week follow-up for patient-reported outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the survival rates of patients with SLE-associated PAH and identify prognostic factors, including the six-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that lower six-minute walking distance (6MWD) was associated with poor survival in SLE-associated PAH patients. The pooled survival rates were 88% at 1 year, 81% at 3 years, and 68% at 5 years.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) over one year as an indicator of exercise capacity in patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure (CHRF) receiving home non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIMV) across different etiologies.
results_summary: The study found that the OHS group had the lowest baseline 6MWD and the highest decrease over one year, while the KS group showed the best baseline values and the most improvement under home NIMV. The 6MWD measurements indicated that exercise capacity improvement in CHRF patients on long-term home NIMV depends on etiological diagnoses.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure (CHRF) due to COPD, obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), kyphoscoliosis (KS), or diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a specific post-stroke motor control deficit (misdirection of ground reaction force) causes observed walking deviations and whether compensatory behaviors counteract this deficit to enable upright posture.
results_summary: The study identified a post-stroke control deficit affecting ground reaction force direction, theorizing that observed gait deviations are compensatory behaviors to counteract this deficit. The alignment between theoretical predictions and clinical observations suggests potential for advancing gait rehabilitation strategies.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with hemiplegic limb impairment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the safety and adherence of an early rehabilitation protocol involving immediate weight-bearing with an ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) after EVFD surgery and to describe gait changes post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the rehabilitation protocol was safe with no clinical complications, improved ankle dorsiflexion, and significant gait parameter changes, including stride length and double support phase duration.
population_specificity: Forty-seven adult hemiplegic patients (20 left-sided, 27 right-sided) with EVFD following ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review interventions promoting walking among children and adolescents to assess their effectiveness in increasing physical activity levels.
results_summary: Nine out of twelve studies reported significant increases in walking in intervention groups compared to controls, particularly in school-based settings. Commonly effective behavior change techniques included goal-setting, feedback, social support, and repetition.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 5-18 years.

study_goal: To determine whether breaking up prolonged sitting with short bouts of standing or walking improves postprandial markers of cardiometabolic health in women at high risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both standing and walking significantly reduced postprandial glucose, insulin, and NEFA responses compared to prolonged sitting, with effects on glucose (standing and walking) and insulin (walking only) persisting into the following day. No significant effect was observed on triglyceride levels.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese, dysglycemic, postmenopausal women (mean age 66.6 ± 4.7 years).
effective_dosage: 5-minute bouts of walking at a self-perceived light intensity every 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of walking speed and mobility response to standard rehabilitation in stroke patients by assessing lesion topography and its impact on therapy outcomes.
results_summary: CST damage predicted response to therapy for general mobility and gait (FAC and MRMI) but not walking speed, which was instead influenced by damage to the putamen, insula, external capsule, and neighboring white matter.
population_specificity: 50 adult-onset stroke patients (3-42 days post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and associated disability of re-harvesting the anterior iliac crest for bone grafts in young adults with repaired clefts.
results_summary: The study found no perioperative complications, no long-term discomfort with walking or other activities, and 97% of patients reported fewer donor-site recovery difficulties during re-harvesting compared to the initial graft.
population_specificity: Young adult patients (14-25 years old) with repaired clefts who had prior anterior iliac crest harvesting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combining fast locomotor training with functional electrical stimulation (FES) on reducing the energy cost of walking and improving long-distance walking ability in poststroke individuals.
results_summary: FastFES training significantly reduced the energy cost of walking (24% at comfortable speed and 19% at fast speed) compared to self-selected or fast walking alone, though no between-group differences were observed in 6-minute walk test gains. A higher proportion of FastFES and Fast participants showed responder status compared to the self-selected speed group.
population_specificity: Fifty participants more than 6 months poststroke.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved 12 weeks of gait training with FES to the paretic ankle musculature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if motivational interviewing could improve physical activity, self-efficacy, quality of life, mobility, and mental health in community-dwelling adults recovering from hip fracture.
results_summary: The motivational interviewing group showed significant improvements in daily steps taken, walking duration, self-efficacy (confidence in walking and not falling), health-related quality of life, and mental health compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adults recovering from hip fracture who were discharged to independent community living.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly sessions of motivational interviewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of bodily illusions, including virtual walking illusions, on pain modulation.
results_summary: Conflicting results were found for virtual walking illusions, with no consistent evidence of pain modulation. Some bodily illusions, such as mirror therapy and bodily resizing, showed therapeutic promise for pain reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies evaluating bodily illusions and pain modulation).
study_duration: Varied (e.g., 4-6 weeks for mirror therapy, single session for some illusions)

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of a structured home-based walking program versus revascularization on quality of life and walking performance in elderly patients with peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: Both the walking program and revascularization improved quality of life and walking distances (ICD, ACD, PFWD), with no significant difference between groups. Revascularization showed greater improvement in 6MWD and ABI, while the walking program had a lower cost per meter gained.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (age 68 ± 7 years) with moderate to severe claudication due to peripheral arterial disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (home-based walking program prescribed and controlled at the hospital).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a home-based resistance-band exercise program on mobility, functional exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life in total hip arthroplasty (THR) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in up-and-go time (40.33% decrease), 6-minute walking distance (41.34% increase), and health-related quality of life (78.94% improvement) after 12 weeks of training. The program was deemed safe, feasible, and effective, with a high adherence rate (72.63%).
population_specificity: 30 patients (21 women, 9 men) aged 55-86 years who underwent total hip replacement for osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different ankle foot orthoses on body functions and activities in people with floppy paretic ankle muscles to aid clinical decision-making and improve adherence.
results_summary: Dorsal, circular, and elastic ankle foot orthoses improved dorsiflexion during swing and push-off moment, but physical comfort varied by orthosis type. People with dorsiflexor paresis benefited more from circular and elastic orthoses, while those with plantar flexor paresis benefited more from dorsal orthoses.
population_specificity: People with floppy paretic ankle muscles (dorsiflexor paresis, plantar flexor paresis, or both).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of gender on 3-year outcomes of endovascular treatments for lesions in the superficial femoral artery and proximal popliteal artery, focusing on walking impairment and clinical scores.
results_summary: Women initially had inferior walking distance scores compared to men, but these equalized by 2 years. However, at 3-year follow-up, women showed less durable results in walking distance and WIQ scores compared to men, though both groups improved from baseline.
population_specificity: 287 patients (190 male, 97 female) with lesions in the superficial femoral artery and proximal popliteal artery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of repeated intrathecal triamcinolone acetonide (TCA) instillations on clinical parameters, including mobility (walking distance and timed 25-foot walk), in MS patients with spasticity unresponsive to common treatments.
results_summary: Repeated TCA treatment showed temporary improvements in spasticity and mobility (walking distance and timed 25-foot walk), but effects diminished over 3 months. No long-lasting improvement in spasticity or disability (EDSS) was observed by the study's end.
population_specificity: 54 patients with clinically definite multiple sclerosis (MS) and no response to common antispastic drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the effects of exercise (including walking) on cognitive function in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and develop a framework for future studies.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that early randomized controlled trials on exercise and cognition in MS show mixed results, but suggests that evidence from the general population supports the benefits of exercise on cognition. The paper proposes applying this evidence-based approach to MS to improve cognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of two balance training devices (stabilometric platform and crossover) for improving balance and walking capacity in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Both training methods improved balance (TUG, BBS, UPDRS II) equally, but crossover training showed better improvement in walking capacity (6MWT).
population_specificity: 60 Parkinson's disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and tolerability of MultiGeneAngio (MGA), a cell-based therapy for claudication due to peripheral artery disease, delivered via intra-arterial infusion.
results_summary: The study found MGA to be well-tolerated and safe, with only one serious adverse event possibly related to treatment. Mean maximal walking time increased from baseline to 1 year, and ankle-brachial index remained unchanged, indicating no safety concerns.
population_specificity: 12 male subjects (mean age 60 ± 5 years), 25% with diabetes mellitus, suffering from claudication due to peripheral artery disease.
effective_dosage: Single intra-arterial infusion of MGA at doses of 1 × 10^7, 2 × 10^7, 5 × 10^7, and 7 × 10^7 cells (equal parts VEGF165-expressing smooth muscle cells and Ang-1-expressing endothelial cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a school-based intervention could increase active commuting (walking/biking) to school and sustain the effects 6 months post-intervention.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased walking and biking frequency at 6-month follow-up, with walking showing the most sustained improvement compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 206 children aged 8-11 years from 5 primary schools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a 6-month exercise programme (OsteoACTIVE) on quadriceps strength, BMD, dynamic balance, walking capacity, physical activity level, and quality of life in postmenopausal women with osteopenia and a previous wrist fracture.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the OsteoACTIVE group and the control group over the 1-year follow-up for any of the outcome measures, including walking capacity.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with low bone mineral density (osteopenia) and a healed wrist fracture.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise programme adherence was 87% on average).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of high-pressure intermittent pneumatic compression (HPIPC) versus standard walking exercise in improving peak walking time, pain relief, and ulcer healing in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) or critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found that HPIPC significantly improved peak walking time, reduced resting pain, and enhanced ulcer healing compared to standard walking exercise, with statistically significant differences at 16 weeks. Walking exercise also showed modest improvements but was less effective than HPIPC.
population_specificity: 34 subjects with symptomatic PAD or CLI experiencing claudication pain, chronic resting pain, numbness, or ischemic ulcers.
